title: 112_s1700
content:
The Act may be cited as the "Medical Device Regulatory Improvement Act" and includes a clarification of the least burdensome. The "Medical Device Regulatory Improvement Act" amends the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act to streamline the premarket approval process for medical devices. The Secretary is required to focus on relevant information for demonstrating device safety and effectiveness, explore alternative evaluation methods to reduce time and cost, use all reasonable means to expedite reviews, and assess if pre-clinical data can meet approval requirements. The "Medical Device Regulatory Improvement Act" streamlines the premarket approval process for medical devices by focusing on relevant information for safety and effectiveness, exploring alternative evaluation methods, and expediting reviews. The Act also emphasizes the use of pre-clinical data when possible to meet approval requirements. The "Medical Device Regulatory Improvement Act" aims to streamline the premarket approval process by focusing on device labeling, considering alternative evaluation methods, and expediting reviews to reduce time and cost. SEC. 3. CONFLICTS OF INTEREST.

Amendment to Section 712 of the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act regarding conflicts of interest in advisory committees providing advice to the FDA. Members are subject to relevant provisions in the Federal Advisory Committee Act and Ethics in Government Act.

SEC. 4. MANAGEMENT AND INNOVATION REVIEW. The Secretary of Health and Human Services must contract with an eligible entity within 60 days to review management and regulatory processes of large organizations. The entity must have experience in evaluating organizational structures and submit an application to the Secretary. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will conduct a review of the management and regulatory processes at the Center for Devices and Radiological Health of the FDA to consider impacts on innovation. A report with findings and recommendations will be submitted to Congress and the Secretary within 1 year. Funding for this review will come from existing resources of the Office of the Secretary.
